newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Strong quarterly results boost Creative.
newsitem.headline: Strong quarterly results boost Creative.

text.p: Better-than-expected second quarter results gave sound card company Creative Technology's shares a boost on Monday.
Analysts said they were confident of a good set of numbers for the full year ending June 1997 and this should give more upside to its share price.
Creative's Singapore shares leapt more than 18 percent, or Singapore S$3.40, to a high of S$21.70 on Monday. It closed at S$21, up S$2.70.
"The results were way above expectations," said Timothy Wong, research manager at Vickers Ballas.
The company said second quarter net profit surged 111 percent to US$56.93 million.
Analysts told Reuters they had doubled their forecasts for Creative's full-year net profit to between US$116 million and US$123 million for the 1997 financial year.
Wong said Creative's shares could go as high as S$23 to $25 based on a price-earnings ratio of about 12-15 times for the current financial year.
Analysts said Creative's impressive performance started from its first quarter results that reversed losses in the two previous quarters.

They said Creative's results had been improving after it instituted expense-control measures and concentrated on higher-end products. Better gross margins at 28 percent gave its second quarter results a big boost.
But analysts said margins might ease in coming quarters.
"Margins may not be sustainable and may dip back to 20-22 percent in the next two quarters," said Patrick Yau, an analyst at Schroders Securities.
Also, the 1998 financial year might pose some challenges, analysts said.
Yau said Creative had benefitted from falling semiconductor prices in 1996 that lifted its margins. This might not happen again in 1998, he said.
As a technology company it might not be able to continue to keep down future expenses, especially for research and development, he said.
Analysts had mixed views on whether competition from Intel's recently launched MMX chip, which has sound capability without the use of a sound card, would dent Creative's market share.

An analyst from a local broking house said Creative's move into digital video disc, a multimedia storage system for computers, TV video and audio systems, augured well for its future earnings, especially its tie-up with Korea's Samsung.
"Creative has realised it can't be a leader in markets dominated by the Japanese and has tied up with Samsung, who will make the DVD drives and Creative will produce the software," the analyst said.
